page.title: 06River Kennet
page.content: Kennet. Mr. Woolnough said that when he first came to his job, the{level of {the water}was{raising}all the time and it had to be controlled by sluice gates to stop flooding. This was because the farmers all drained their land into the river, but during the last ten years the{level of the river has{fallen}rapidly. This is because the town of Swindon, which is fifteen miles away, takes the water from the Kennet to use as the domestic supply. (I think it is also the industrial supply too). When the water has been used it is pumped back into the River Thames. This means that there is not a great deal of pollution in the river but it does mean that the weeds which grow along the banks are continuously losing the mud and water from around their roots.It also means that nettles which root easily, soon spring up
